name: Hector XT
keyboard: Full-stroke 84 key with numeric keypad and function keys
ports: eight internal 8 bit ISA slots, Serial RS232, Parallel Centronics
description:
After having given up home computers market, Micronique recentred on the professional market and released PC compatible systems.

They were standard systems. Mother board was made by Micronique but all other components were imported from Far East and assembled in France.

The system pictured is a 'turbo' PC-XT model. Micronique also launched an AT 286 computer before definitively giving up the computers market and going back to its initial line of business, electronic components manufacturing.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover of a Tandy catalogue.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Chuck Hunkle, who worked at MSI in 1977-79, kindly sent us the complete 1978 MSI catalog. All the pages are shown in the following pictures.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY.  (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666">             The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br>             The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br>             At $595 it is astonishing.<br>             Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br>             Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br>             If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived...  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/">ITSR'S NES ARCHIVE</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Strange logo isn't it?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the computing answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TTX 80 FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"computing against wasted time"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> CORTEX has been designed not to dominate your desk, to leave room for your calendar, your telephone, your in-tray and the rest. If you want it inconspicuous, buy iy in conventional cream. But for extroverts, and the fashion conscious, CORTEX comes in bright, bright colours - warm red, C/WP green, sunshine yellow, ice white and all black...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Guizzi (http://www.scribd.com/doc/938905/Micro-Sistemas)</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> The ATOM -a definitive personal computer. Simple-to-build, simple-to-operate. But a really powerful full-facility computer. And designed on an expandable basis. You can buy a superb expanded package now-tailored to your needs. Or, you can buy just the standard Atom kit, and, as you grow in confidence and knowledge, add more chips. No need to replace your equipment. No need to worry that your investment will be overtaken by new technology. As you need more power, more facilities, you can add them! <br><br> <b>The standard ATOM kit includes:</b><br> . Full sized QWERTY keyboard. Rugged polystyrene case<br> . Fibreglass PCB. 2K RAM. 8K ROM. 23 integrated circuits . Full assembly instructions including tests for fault-finding. (Once built, connect it to any domestic TV and power source)<br> . Power requirement: 8V at 800 M A. ATOM power unit available.<br> PLUS FREE MANUAL written in two sections <br> - teach yourself BASIC and machine code for those with no knowledge of computers, and a reference section giving a complete description of the ATOM's facilities. All sections are fully illustrated with example programs.<br><br> <b>The ATOM concept</b><br> Adding chips into sockets on the PCB allows you to progress in affordable steps to large-scale expansion. You can see from the specifications that the RAM can be increased to 12K allowing high resolution (256 x 192) graphics. Two further ROM chips, e.g. maths functions, can be added directly to the board giving a 16K capacity. In addition to 5 I/O lines partly used by the cassette interface, an optional VIA device can provide varied I/O and timer functions and via a buffer device allow direct printer drive. An optional module provides red, green and blue signals for colour. An in-board connector strip takes the ATOM communications loop interface. Any number of ATOMs may be tinked to each other - or to a master system with mass storage, hard copy facility. Interface with other ACORN cards is simplicity itself. Anyone ACORN card may be fitted internally. So you can see there are a vast number of modular options and additions available, expanding with your ability and your budget.<br><br> <b>The ATOM hardware includes:</b><br> .Memory from 2K to 12K RAM on board (up to 35K in case)<br> .8K to 16K ROM (two 4K additions) 86502 processor<br> .Video Display allows high resolution (256 x 192) graphics and red, green and blue output<br> .Cassette Interface-CUTS 300 baud<br> .Loudspeaker allows tone generation of any frequency<br> .Channel36 UHF Modulator Output .Bus output includes internal connections for Acorn Eurocard.<br><br> <b>The ATOM software includes:</b><br> .32-bit arithmetic (+/- 2,000,000,000)<br> .High speed execution<br> .43 standard/extended BASIC commands <br> .Variable length strings (up to 256 characters)<br> .String manipulation functions<br> .27 32-bit integer variables<br> .27 additional arrays<br> .random number function .PUT and GET byte<br> .WAIT command for timing<br> .DO-UNTIL construction<br> .Logical operators (AND, OR, EX-OR)<br> .LINK to machine-code routines<br> .Plot draw and move. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Paul Durrant</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated december 1980</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, NOV. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
